entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 4 at 6:22AM MST by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Sawtooth Avalanche Center.
...The Forest Service Sawtooth Avalanche Center in Ketchum Idaho has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING...
* WHAT...The avalanche danger is HIGH and EXTREME. Extraordinarily dangerous avalanche conditions exist.
* WHERE...The southern Salmon River, Sawtooth, western Smoky, Smoky, White Cloud, Boulder, Pioneer, and Soldier Mountainsincluding the mountains near Banner Summit, Atlanta, Stanley, Smiley Creek, Galena Summit, Ketchum, Hailey, and Fairfield.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 06:00 MST to Wed 06:00 MST.
* IMPACTS...A powerful multi-day storm continues to overload a very weak snowpack. Natural and human-triggered avalanches large enough to bury people are almost certain. Some avalanches will be large enough to snap trees and damage structures.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Boise, ID; Camas, ID; Elmore, ID; Valley, ID

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued February 4 at 3:21AM HST until February 4 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF ADVISORY FOR NORTH FACING SHORES OF NIIHAU KAUAI OAHU MOLOKAI MAUI AND THE BIG ISLAND...
.A reinforcing moderate to large north to north-northeast (10-30 degrees) swell will hold today then gradually diminish through the rest of the week. Another moderate reinforcing northeast swell is possible around Thursday.
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 10 to 16 feet.
* WHERE...North facing shores of Kauai, Maui, Molokai, Niihau, Oahu and the Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Moderate. Strong breaking waves and strong currents will make swimming dangerous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Niihau; Oahu North Shore; Olomana; Maui Windward West; Kauai North; Kauai East; Koolau Windward; Molokai Windward; Molokai North; Maui Central Valley North; Windward Haleakala; Big Island East; Big Island North

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 5:16AM PST until February 7 at 11:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Medford OR has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in California...
Pit River near Canby affecting Modoc County.
For the Pit River...including Canby...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* WHERE...Pit River near Canby.
* WHEN...From early this morning to late Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Expect significant flooding in southwest Modoc and northwest Lassen counties. 4900 cfs
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:45 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 9.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 0.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:45 AM PST Tuesday was 9.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.7 feet late this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late Friday morning. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.8 feet on 04/05/1955. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 5:14AM PST until February 4 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues.
* WHERE...A portion of northern California, including the following counties, Modoc and southeastern Siskiyou, and the cities of Alturas, Adin, Canby, Pondosa, and McCloud.
* WHEN...Until at least 1000 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 514 AM PST, Heavy rain and snowmelt is occurring, and will cause flooding. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen, and an additional 2 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. - This includes the following streams and drainages... Little Castle Creek, Edson Creek, Dry Creek, McKay Creek, Huckleberry Creek, Big Canyon Creek, Ash Creek, McCloud River, Bear Creek, Trout Creek, Squaw Valley Creek, Cold Creek, Pole Creek, Pilgrim Creek, Castle Lake Creek, Soda Creek, Sacramento River, Hedge Creek, North Fork Bear Creek, Panther Creek and Angel Creek.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include... Mount Shasta, Alturas, Dunsmuir, Howards Gulch Campground, Canby, Lower Rush Creek Campground, Adin, Lookout, Lava Lake Campground, Tionesta, Day, Likely, Pondosa, Willow Ranch, Cattle Camp Campground, Pilgrim Creek Snow Park, Fowlers Camp Campground And McCloud Falls and McCloud. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Modoc, CA; Siskiyou, CA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM PST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 3:55AM PST until February 5 at 2:15AM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in California...
Eel River at Fernbridge affecting Humboldt County.
For the Eel River...including Fernbridge, Scotia, Bridgeville, Fort Seward, Miranda...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Eel River at Fernbridge.
* WHEN...Until late tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 24.0 feet, Minor flooding of Highway 211 to Ferndale south of Fernbridge. Much of the Eel Delta may be flooded, including areas northwest of Loleta and the western portion of Cannibal Island Road. Flooding will be enhanced for longer duration events. A Special Action Advisory is being issued to all owners of livestock in all low-lying areas adjacent to the Eel River. Appropriate action should be taken to protect livestock.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 23.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 20.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:15 AM PST Tuesday was 23.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this evening and begin to pulse again early Wednesday morning, approaching Minor flood stage of around 20 feet. River stage is forecasted to fall below Action stage by Wednesday late night.. - Flood stage is 20.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 23.7 feet on 12/19/1981. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Humboldt, CA

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 3:33AM PST until February 5 at 7:00PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Sacramento CA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in California...
Sacramento River Below Red Bluff Diversion Dam affecting Tehama County.
.A series of strong winter storms will bring periods of moderate to heavy rainfall to Northern California through the end of the week. This will result in significant rises along the mainstem Sacramento River and its tributaries.
For the Upper Sacramento River...including Red Bluff Diversion Dam, Tehama Bridge, Vina Woodson Bridge, Ord Ferry...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sacramento River below Red Bluff Diversion Dam.
* WHEN...From late tonight to tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 256.6 feet, Overflow of east bank of river downstream of gage begins. Housing development in the area is threatened.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:30 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 249.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 252.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 255.6 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight. - Flood stage is 255.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 255.5 feet on 12/11/2014. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tehama, CA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT TO TOMORROW EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 3:33AM PST until February 6 at 12:24PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in California...
Sacramento River At Vina Woodson Bridge affecting Tehama County.
Sacramento River At Tehama Bridge affecting Tehama County.
Sacramento River At Ord Ferry affecting Glenn and Butte Counties.
.A series of strong winter storms will bring periods of moderate to heavy rainfall to Northern California through the end of the week. This will result in significant rises along the mainstem Sacramento River and its tributaries.
For the Upper Sacramento River...including Red Bluff Diversion Dam, Tehama Bridge, Vina Woodson Bridge, Ord Ferry...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sacramento River at Tehama Bridge.
* WHEN...Until early Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 206.7 feet, Water into rv park on east side of river. Tires of trailers get wet. At 209.7 feet, Flood stage - Road inside trailer park and turn around site under RR tracks (Tehama/Vina road) become impassible. Water is into area around structures on east side of river. No structural damage. Sheriff's office issues advisory. Makes sure Pelhams Bay, Snug Harbor, River Inn (small trailer parks all in a row on east side of river north of bridge) know of advisory. At 210.7 feet, Between 210 and 211 feet the county park becomes inaccessible. At 211 feet water begins to enter Driftwood RV fishing resort on east bank of river and just north of the county park. At 214.7 feet, Pelams Resort access road floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 209.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 206.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM PST Tuesday was 213.4 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall below flood stage early this morning to 209.3 feet this morning. It will then rise above flood stage this morning to 213.6 feet late tonight. It will fall below flood stage again tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 209.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 213.5 feet on 12/02/2012. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tehama, CA

* WHEN...From this morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 110.3 feet, Head cuts in 3Bs silt weir start overflow into Butte Basin, flooding dips on Ord Ferry Road west of River Road. Persistent flows at or above this level increase flooding in Butte Basin. Ord Ferry Road and additional roads in Glenn and Colusa counties are closed due to flooding. At 113.8 feet, Design overflow level for M&T, 3Bs and Goose Lake flood control facilities to divert flood flows into Butte Basin. M&T overflows close River Road from Ord Ferry Road to Chico Road. Ord Ferry Road is already closed. At 114.0 feet, Designated flood stage left bank.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 111.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 114.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning and continue rising to 115.6 feet late tomorrow evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 114.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 115.5 feet on 01/10/2017. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butte, CA; Glenn, CA

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 3:29AM CST until February 5 at 2:34AM CST by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Kentucky...
Green River at Rochester affecting Muhlenberg, Butler and Ohio Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Green River at Rochester.
* WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 34.0 feet, Rochester Ferry stops operation. At 37.0 feet, Reeds and Rochester Ferries remain closed. KY 369 floods one mile north of Rochester.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 AM CST Tuesday the stage was 38.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 34.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:45 AM CST Tuesday was 38.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this evening and continue falling to 32.8 feet Saturday evening. - Flood stage is 37.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 39.0 feet on 03/22/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butler, KY; Muhlenberg, KY; Ohio, KY

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 4 at 1:17AM PST until February 5 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northern California, including the following areas, Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County and Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. There is the potential for mud and rock slides in the foothills and mountains.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Periods of moderate to heavy rainfall are expected over the next 24 hours with additional totals from 1 to 3 inches in the foothills and 2 to 5 inches in the mountains below 3500 feet. Heaviest period of rain will be through this afternoon. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County; Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued February 4 at 2:17AM MST until February 5 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY WEDNESDAY EVENING FOR MUCH OF NORTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL NM DUE TO VERY LOW HUMIDITY AND WINDY CONDITIONS...
.Strong and gusty westerly downslope winds will develop late Wednesday morning east of the Sangre De Cristo and Sandia Mountains to the TX and OK borders, then continue into the early evening hours. In addition, minimum humidity will reach down into the high single digits and high temperatures will challenge daily record values. This comes on the heels of several days of well above normal temperatures and very dry conditions.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Wednesday morning through Wednesday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Highlands (Zone 123), Northeast Plains (Zone 104), Central Highlands (Zone 125) and the East Central Plains (Zone 126) from late Wednesday morning through early Wednesday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with occasional gusts to between 40 and 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 13 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Northeast Highlands; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY WEDNESDAY EVENING

Mountains and mountain passes will see higher amounts of up to 18 inches. For lower elevations, including Salmon, precipitation may change over to freezing rain for a period of time Tuesday, making for icy conditions.
* WHERE...Highway 28 Tendoy to Lone Pine, Williams Creek Summit, Highway 93 Lost Trail Pass to Gibbonsville, Bannock Pass, Salmon, Shoup, and Lemhi Pass.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM MST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...For MINOR impacts from snow, expect a few inconveniences to normal activities. Use caution while driving. For MODERATE impacts from snow, expect disruptions to normal activities. Hazardous traveling conditions. Use extra caution while driving. Closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes, especially over higher passes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Lemhi County; Eastern Lemhi County

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued February 3 at 1:15PM MST until February 5 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow expected. Likelihood of minor to moderate impacts from around 1 to 3 inches of snow is 90 percent, and 3 to 6 inches of snow is 40 percent. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy snow and blowing snow possible. Chance of moderate to major impacts from snow is at least 50 percent. Total snow accumulations between 5 and 10 inches possible between Libby and Marion.
* WHERE...Highway 56 Bull Lake Road, Highway 37 Eureka to Libby, Highway 2 Kalispell to Libby, and Highway 93 Eureka to Whitefish.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, from 11 PM this evening to 5 PM MST Tuesday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...For MODERATE impacts from snow, expect disruptions to normal activities. Hazardous traveling conditions. Use extra caution while driving. Closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. For MAJOR impacts from snow, expect considerable disruptions to normal activities. Dangerous or impossible traveling conditions. Avoid travel in the impacted areas if possible. Widespread closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning and evening commutes, especially over higher passes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Gusty easterly winds between 10 and 20 mph will bring blowing and drifting snow.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kootenai/Cabinet Region

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 3 at 12:08PM PST until February 6 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Major Flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Along Pit River and tributaries in Northwest Lassen County including Big Valley, Bieber, and Nubieber.
* WHEN...Until noon PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Major flooding from the Pit river and tributaries are expected to impact Northwest Lassen County. Inundation and damage to roads, agricultural areas, and low lying homes and structures in Big valley including Bieber and Nubieber. The current forecast peaks at a similar level to the February 2017 flood event.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1202 PM PST, Major flooding is forecasted by the California-Nevada River Forecast Center. The Pit River near Canby is forecast to peak near major flood stage late Tuesday into Wednesday. Flood flows from the Pit river will be joined by numerous tributaries below the Canby gage. These tributaries are already leading to flooding impacts in Big Valley. Flood prone structures in Bieber and New Bieber, should prepare now. - Check cnrfc.noaa.gov for updated river forecasts. The CNRFC will updated forecasts 4 times per by 9am, 3pm, 9pm, and 3am through Tuesday night. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Nubieber, Bieber, Pittville and Ca 299 At Shasta-Lassen Co Line. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen, CA

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 3 at 12:01PM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Hydrologic flooding caused by excessive rainfall and snowmelt is ongoing.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast California, including the following county, Lassen.
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Renewed rainfall this afternoon through Tuesday may lead to additional rises on already high rivers and streams and exacerbate ponding in poor drainage areas. A second rise to flood stage is possible on the Susan River at Susanville if the rain/snow elevation is higher than currently expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1157 AM PST, Rain and snowmelt will cause minor flooding. - More significant flooding is forecast for the Pit River in Northwest Lassen County. See the separate flood warning for additional details on the Pit River. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Eagle Lake, Termo, Bieber, Herlong, Nubieber, Doyle, Susanville, Spaulding, Aspen Grove Campground, Standish, Janesville, Madeline, Crater Lake Campground, Westwood, Pittville, Chilcoot-Vinton, Hallelujah Junction, Eagle Campground, Merrill Campground and Ravendale. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen, CA

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 3 at 7:05AM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
AVWTFX
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE GALLATIN NATIONAL FOREST AVALANCHE CENTER.
ISSUED ON February 03 2024 AT 546 AM
The Gallatin NF Avalanche Center in Bozeman has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING
* WHAT...The avalanche danger is HIGH on all slopes. Natural and human-triggered slides are very likely.
* WHERE...The mountains around West Yellowstone and Island Park.
* WHEN...In effect from Mon 546 AM to Tue 0546 AM.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snowfall on a weak snowpack is creating very dangerous avalanche conditions.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Very dangerous avalanche conditions exist. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended. Avoid traveling on or under slopes steeper than 30 degrees. Avalanches may be triggered from flat terrain underneath steeper slopes.
Consult http://www.mtavalanche.com or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
Avalanche Hotline: 406-587-6981
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gallatin and Madison County Mountains and Centennial Mountains
